items.title: Search engine optimization of librosa doc
items.body:
Googling something like "librosa mfcc" doesn't do a very good job at finding librosa documentation. The first result is this dubious website (http://man.hubwiz.com/docset/LibROSA.docset/Contents/Resources/Documents/generated/librosa.feature.mfcc.html) that copied librosa 0.6.0 documentation. At the moment, the 8th result is the first librosa webpage and it's librosa 0.7.1 documentation and the link is broken. 

I don't have any knowledge about how, but is it something we want to fix a bit?

items.title: Draw f0 on cqt's image

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

items.body:
# Draw f0 on cqt's image

Draw f0 on cqt's image for users to read note's name directly

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I'm always frustrated when trying to draw a f0 line into a cqt image.

I use `code1` to draw cqt_note - time image. I find it useful because I can read the name of the notes directly from y-axis.

```python
# code1
y, sr = librosa.load("F:\\Script\\Voice\\music\\human.wav", duration=15.0, sr=None)
C = librosa.cqt(y=y, sr=sr)
C_db = librosa.amplitude_to_db(np.abs(C), ref=np.max)
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
img = librosa.display.specshow(C_db, sr=sr, y_axis='cqt_note', x_axis='time', ax=ax, cmap='gray_r')
fig.colorbar(img, ax=ax, format='%+2.0f dB')
plt.show()
```

But, the [pyin](https://librosa.org/doc/latest/generated/librosa.pyin.html#librosa.pyin) didn't suppprt it, I can draw f0 line by log y-axis in ‘ferequency-time' image, but I can not directly read out the note's name on the y-axis.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Provide a new function[let's call it`note_0()`]. and the output could be added to the cqt's 'ax' object, just like drawing pyin's output on 'db-time' image

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

I tried to slove it in a physical way. I set all the figures to a certain size, then, mark the notes in one picture's y-axis by a pen.

Then, I cut it off, and use this piece of paper as a ruler, but it is very funny, and I have to copy the 'ruler' a lot of times.:cry:

**Additional context**

I want to get a <u>'line'</u> of f0, not a number of rectangle(s) filled by a color.

*this function is very useful for musicians.*

Thanks for your reading

items.title: Adding `write` support into librosa

labels.name: IO
labels.description: Issues relating to reading and writing (audio) data

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: Issues that we don't want to deal with: out of scope, intended behavior, deprecations, etc.

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Librosa's `load` function works well and with a variety of different audio formats. However, there is no functionality for writing files within librosa, and thus I am forced to use `soundfile`'s write function which doesn't support popular audio formats such as MP3. This has been quite frustrating for me.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Ideally, it would be amazing if librosa had a built-in function, perhaps similar to the format of `librosa.load` for writing -- i.e. try soundfile's write and if it doesn't work, resort to something else. This function would support popular audio format types such as MP3, AAC, etc.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I've looked around *extensively* for other options for writing audio files with no luck. I've looked at FFMPEG (which in my experience hasn't worked well with audio numpy arrays), at pydub (that has been supremely buggy), and all kinds of libraries on the internet. 


Thanks in advance for your help! If you are incapable of adding this feature, I'd greatly appreciate some pointers for libraries that will take as input an audio array, the sample rate, and the output file and save the audio.

items.title: Feature extractor: instantaneous frequency

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

[GANSynth](https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.08710) and [this work](https://www.math.ucdavis.edu/~saito/data/sonar/boashash1.pdf) discuss the instantaneous frequency. This would be a useful feature to extract.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

One simplified way to compute the IF, shared with me by @maxsolomonhenry, is as follows:

```
    cqt_ = librosa.cqt(y=y, sr=sr)
    IF = np.diff(np.unwrap(np.angle(cqt_)))
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Search for alternate implementations, or not use this feature.

items.title: 【Qusetion】about【power_to_db】

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

items.body:
Hi, Librosa Team:
I have two qusetions about the I/O "power_to_db"
When I use this I/O, it will return a 2d array. for further usage, I append each of these into a list. This is my code
```python
def anal_list(in_put):
    """[1, 2, 3]
    [4, 5, 6]
    [7, 8, 9]
    ->([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8, 9]], 3)"""
    length_list: list = []
    output_list: list = []
    for x in in_put:
        output_list.append(list(x))
        length_list.append(x.shape[0])
    return output_list, max(length_list)
    # the list I am talking about is "output_list"
```
And I discover that the list has 1025 child list(index:0 - 1024)
====QUENSTION ONE====
The fig I got shows that the frequency "power_to_db"could analyse is in the range of 0-8192 and I guess each child list means a 'left-to-right' line. But I can't make sure what is the relationship between the Ordinate(Y-frequency) and the index of these child list?
What is the direction plt draw as the index increase?Does plt draw 'up-to down' or 'down-to-up'?
Or, in another word, let Y-frequency = f(index), please show me the f(x) or just show me the code that caculates the Y-frequency?
====QUENSTION TWO====
Each child list contains a lot of int-kind data. let's call their index in its list as 'index2'.
Plt would translate these data into a lot of dot, let's call the Abscissa of each dot as 'X-time'.
I am sure that the 'X-time' have some connection with 'X-time',  and also the sr of the audio I loaded.
Let X-time = g(index2, sr), please show me the expression of g(x, y), or show me the code that caculates g(x, y).
[Just use g(index2, sr), instead of g(x, y), to make it readable]
thank you very much ;)
Please forgive me for any possible grammar or spelling mistakes ~~and this silly qestion~~:smile:.

items.title: Librosa seems to write files with `y.dtype=float64` default.

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: Issues that we don't want to deal with: out of scope, intended behavior, deprecations, etc.

items.body:
***BEFORE POSTING A BUG REPORT*** Please look through [existing issues (both open and closed)](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/issues?q=is%3Aissue) to see if it's already been reported or fixed!


**Describe the bug**
One of the options that librosa offers is to load a audio time series' `dtype` as a certain type (usually only 'float32' or 'float64' works for writing which is understandable). However, I have noticed that when I alter a `y` to be of `dtype=float32`, once loading the file, it is in `float64`. My question is: does librosa actually write the file as float64 regardless using my machine, or does it just load the file as float64?

Look at the code below to display what I mean:

**To Reproduce**

Example:
```
y, sr = librosa.load("audio_file", mono=False, sr=None, dtype='float32')
print(y.dtype) # float32
librosa.output.write_wav("output_audio_path", y, sr)
y, sr = librosa.load("output_audio_path", mono=False, sr=None, dtype=None)
print(y.dtype) #float64
```

I load the file to be dtype=float32, and verify that it is, but when I write the file and load it again (this time saying dtype=None to avoid any modification), it loads `y` with `dtype=float64`. Why is that?

items.title: display.cmap should return binary colormaps for binary data

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
`cmap()` infers an appropriate colormap based on the characteristics of the data.
If the `dtype` is boolean, it returns a `gray_r` colormap.
The colormap returned has 256 values by default, so colorbars show up as continuous.
However, we know that the data will be binary, so it should instead fix the number of values to 2 and provide a discrete map.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/6f609e6b664d5a17f6a5a60e438c46318957975a/librosa/display.py#L343

should be modified to call `get_cmap(cmap_bool, lut=2)`.

items.title: Should specshow return the QuadMesh instead of axes?

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

items.body:
`display.specshow` returns as its output the (current) axes handle on which the data is rendered by `pcolormesh`.

This was done primarily to make it easy to use with the `pyplot` interface, where axes can be constructed on the fly.  Since `specshow` does multiple things to the figure (locations, decorations, image, etc), it seemed at the time of implementation that returning the axes handle was the most useful thing.  (IIRC, this was originally done to make interaction with ipython notebooks easy, but this has long since become unnecessary.)

However, this does make it a little unwieldy to use with the object API, which is what the matplotlib authors generally recommend should be used.  Specifically, if you want to add a colorbar to a specshow output, the recommended process is to say
```python
fig.colorbar(mappable, ax=ax)
```
where `fig` is the figure, `ax` is the axes handle, and `mappable` is the color-mappable object (eg an image plotted by `imshow`).
We currently support this in the stateful API by setting the current image state to the drawn `pcolormesh` object, but otherwise do not expose this to the user.  This means that a user would have to dig into the axes artist handles to extract the `QuadMesh` object, and then pass it into `fig.colorbar`.

If instead, we let specshow return the quadmesh, then you can do:
```python
>>> img = librosa.display.specshow(...)
>>> fig.colorbar(img, ax=ax)
```
which I think meets the general API expectations for matplotlib.

Note that this does not conflict with the stateful API, since we can still `plt.sci()` (if in the stateful use-case) and `plt.colorbar()` will continue to work.
What would change is that a user in the object interface would not receive a direct handle to the axes object.  I'd argue that this is fine, because the object interface use pattern would construct the axes first:
```python
>>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()
>>> librosa.display.specshow(..., ax=ax)
```
In the stateful interface, a user could just as easily call `plt.gca()` if they need the axes handle.

This would be an API breaking change, but I expect it would be a minimal one.  If we do it, it should be at the 0.8 release.

Side note: `waveplot` already behaves in the analogous way, returning the `PolyCollection` created by `fill_between` rather than the axes handle.  So there's also an argument to be made that this change would be more internally consistent as well.

---
This is prompted by work in #1178 , where modernizing the example code led to issues with colorbars.  I'll block that PR until this issue is resolved.

items.title: Why are features at STFT based upon n_fft and not fft_size?

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

items.body:
**Describe the bug**

https://librosa.org/librosa/generated/librosa.core.stft.html

'n_fft:int > 0 [scalar]
length of the windowed signal after padding with zeros. The number of rows in the STFT matrix D is (1 + n_fft/2). The default value, n_fft=2048 samples, corresponds to a physical duration of 93 milliseconds at a sample rate of 22050 Hz, i.e. the default sample rate in librosa. '

How can n_fft=2048 samples, corresponds to a physical duration of 93 milliseconds at a sample rate of 22050 Hz unless you assume n_samples = 190464?

Or is n_fft actually the fft_size, which would in fact correspond to 93 ms per window? Is the documentation wrong?

https://librosa.org/librosa/glossary.html indicates that n_fft is the window_size. But with 2.5 seconds or 22050 Hz audio, we get 109 frames from every feature extractor (except fourier_tempogram which bizarrely has 110 frames), using the default params for every feature extractor. This corresponds to 505.7339 as the window_size, which doesn't make sense to us.

Expected behavior
The documentation should be updated to describe the behavior of n_fft assuming different audio lengths, or changed to fft_size.

If I use `512` or `2048` with 2.533 sec of audio, I shouldn't have 109 windows for both. But I do:

```
        if feat in [chroma_cqt, chroma_cens]:
            z = feat(x, window=512)
        elif feat in [rms, zero_crossing_rate]:

            z = feat(x, chroma=chroma_cqt(x, window=512))
        else:
            z = feat(x, n_fft=512)
```

items.title: Change default bins_per_octave in chroma_cqt?

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

items.body:
The `chroma_cqt` function has a default of 12 bins per octave in its underlying CQT call.  This produces a pretty noisy chroma feature, which can be significantly cleaned up by increasing the CQT resolution, as documented in our chroma example notebook.  For example:

```python
y, sr = librosa.load(librosa.ex('nutcracker'), duration=5, offset=10)
C12 = librosa.feature.chroma_cqt(y=y, sr=sr)
C24 = librosa.feature.chroma_cqt(y=y, sr=sr, bins_per_octave=24)
C36 = librosa.feature.chroma_cqt(y=y, sr=sr, bins_per_octave=36)
```
produces the following:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1190540/85144328-053c8400-b219-11ea-99ac-5414cb2ca62f.png)
(**EDIT: updated 2020-06-19 to correct the third plot**)


What do folks think about increasing the default resolution in 0.8?  I see no downside to this, other than a slight break of backward compatibility.  But it seems worth it to me.

items.title: Issue in example code for LPC

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Issues relating to docstrings, examples, and documentation build

items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The second example of `librosa.core.lpc` shows how to create the LPC estimate of a time series:
```
>>> a = librosa.lpc(y, 2)
>>> y_hat = scipy.signal.lfilter([0] + -1*a[1:], [1], y)
```
For this, one has to create a vector `[0, -a[1], -a[2], ...]`. However, this doesn't happen here, instead a vector `[-a[1], -a[2], ...]` is created.

The reason is that `List + List` is a concatenation (which is what we want here), but `List + NumPy Array` converts the List to a NumPy Array first, thus adding 0 to each element. The estimated filter coefficients of `librosa.core.lpc` are a NumPy Array. Simple example:
```
>>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3])
>>> [0] + a
array([1, 2, 3])
```
Possible solutions would be:

1) Convert the NumPy Array to a List, then the plus operator will perform concatenation:
```
>>> [0] + a.tolist()
[0, 1, 2, 3]
```
2) Use the `np.hstack` function:
```
>>> np.hstack([[0], a])
array([0, 1, 2, 3])
```

**To Reproduce**
The effect of this can be seen best when using LPC to estimate a sinusoidal signal:
```
import librosa
import numpy as np
import scipy
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

y = np.sin(2.0 * np.pi * 0.1 * np.arange(100))
a = librosa.lpc(y, 2)
y_hat_old = scipy.signal.lfilter([0] + -1*a[1:], [1], y)
y_hat_new = scipy.signal.lfilter(np.hstack([[0], -1*a[1:]]), [1], y)

plt.figure()
plt.plot(y, '-*')
plt.plot(y_hat_old, '--*')
plt.plot(y_hat_new, ':*')
plt.legend(['y', 'y_hat_old', 'y_hat-new'])
plt.show()
```
The resulting plot is:
![LPC Issue Plot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2952672/84860873-26ae3c00-b070-11ea-8d8c-6588fd9005cb.png)

**Expected behavior**
I'd expect `y_hat` to exactly match `y` after the transient-in at the beginning. With the proposed new code, this happens. With the existing code, `y_hat` has an offset in the time-domain by one sample, making the resulting signal appear "too early".

**Software versions***
```
>>> import platform; print(platform.platform())
Linux-4.15.0-106-generic-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-18.04-bionic
>>> import sys; print("Python", sys.version)
Python 3.6.9 (default, Apr 18 2020, 01:56:04)
```

The future URL for this would be `https://librosa.org/docs/`, which makes a bit more sense than `/librosa`.

items.title: Support key in note conversion and display formatting

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Converting from numerical frequency representations (midi, hz) to note names is currently pretty limited.  The core of this conversion is implemented in `midi_to_note` here:
https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/3f59a4f2131751813192cfadd7f91dc7153a51e8/librosa/core/time_frequency.py#L602-L604

which can only use sharps to denote (assumed) accidentals.

This is carried through to display functions, where the tick locator for `chroma` assumes a `C:maj` reference and only notates the white keys:
https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/3f59a4f2131751813192cfadd7f91dc7153a51e8/librosa/display.py#L873-L878

and again, there is no way to for a user to easily change this behavior.

While the current behavior isn't exactly "wrong" (since it can be unambiguously translated back to correct numbers), it's not as useful as it could be.  For instance, if we know we're in `C#:maj`, then it would be more useful to label note 60 as `B#3` than as `C4`.  More generally, if a key is given, we can select the representation which minimizes the total number of accidentals used (sharps vs flats).

**Describe the solution you'd like**

1. Add a `key=` parameter to all `.._note()` converters, which controls how sharps and flats are used in terms of 12*2 major/minor keys specified in the usual way (`C:maj`, `Eb:min`, etc).  We should still keep accidental notations in the output to avoid ambiguities downstream.  No `key=` parameter should be necessary in the reverse converters.
2. Add `key=` parameter to display functions to govern A) ticker locations coincident with scale notes, B) how note strings are represented (using (1)).


**Further points to consider**

There will be some edge cases to handle, eg double-sharps/flats like note 67 in `G#:maj` should be `F##` and not `G`.  We already handle multiple-accidentals in the inverse conversions, so this isn't a huge problem, but we should make sure to get it right.

Another point we could consider in relation to this: would it make sense to add unicode accidental notation support?  We currently use `#` and `b` or `!` to denote sharps and flats, but we could easily add support for `♯` (sharp), `𝄪` (double-sharp), `♭` (flat), `𝄫` (double-flat).  This would make the display functions look a bit nicer, but it could do quirky things to any downstream code which relies on note converters outputting low-order ascii.  (I don't think there's very much of this out there to worry about, but one never knows.)  I'd be okay with making this the default, but allowing a `unicode=False` override to use the old symbols if a user wants that.  Adding it at the note-parsing (`note_to_midi`) stage seems like a no-brainer though.

items.title: power/amplitude bug in _signal_to_frame_nonsilent
items.body:
`_signal_to_frame_nonsilent` implements the following logic.
```
    # Convert to mono
    y_mono = core.to_mono(y)

    # Compute the MSE for the signal
    mse = feature.rms(y=y_mono,
                      frame_length=frame_length,
                      hop_length=hop_length)**2

    return (core.power_to_db(mse.squeeze(),
                             ref=ref,
                             top_db=None) > - top_db)
```

The call to `core.power_to_db` should be replaced with `amplitude_to_db` since the variable `mse` actually does not hold the mean power per frame, but the square root of it by definition of RMS.


**Software versions**

```
Windows-10-10.0.18362-SP0
Python 3.6.8 (tags/v3.6.8:3c6b436a57, Dec 24 2018, 00:16:47) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
NumPy 1.16.6
SciPy 1.3.3
librosa 0.6.3
INSTALLED VERSIONS
------------------
```

items.title: More intelligent dtype inference

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Instigated from #1074 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Many of our functions (eg `stft`) have a `dtype=` parameter with a coded default value (eg `complex64`).

We could probably do a better job of adapting to input precision on the fly, without losing any expected behavior.  EG, if `stft` is given a `float32` input, its output should be `complex64`; if the input is `float64`, it could automatically shift up to `complex128` (unless overridden by the user).

Implementing this would probably require some helper methods to infer the correct precision for converting between real and complex, but I see no downside to doing this.

items.title: Should discontiguous audio be valid?

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

items.body:
Since merging #1125 , we no longer have a strict requirement for the input to `util.frame` to be contiguous.  A discontiguous buffer will be copied to a proper arrangement to support framing.

Relatedly, `util.valid_audio` requires that the input buffer be F-contiguous to pass as valid.  This requirement was originally put in to ensure that framing can operate smoothly if the audio buffer is valid.

The question now is: should we relax the requirement in `valid_audio`?

*Why does this matter*: if we want to make a multi-dimensional STFT, it will need to frame a multi-channel input: `(2, N) -> (2, NFFT, F)`.  However, soundfile returns C-contiguous buffers, and the whole thing breaks.  If we relax the requirement in `valid_audio`, then the whole thing can proceed as expected, if not quite as efficiently as possible.

Related issue: #1130

items.title: Python pitch shifting with window size

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

items.body:
I am attempting to create a sort of autotune/pitch correction algorithm in Python. I am able to detect pitches per a rectangular window size, and tried shifting the pitch of each window (of size 512) by 2 semitones to test if this method would actually work. Doing this, however, creates a huge amount of feedback in the returned audio. I assume this is due to the presence of a rectangular window, instead of a hanning window. My question is, how do I implement pitch correction on bins while also removing the feedback?

Code:
```
import librosa
import librosa.display
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import IPython.display as ipd
import random

samples, sr = librosa.load('my_raw_vocals.wav',sr=None)

def manipulate(data, sampling_rate, pitch_factor):
    return librosa.effects.pitch_shift(data, sampling_rate, pitch_factor)

def block(array, size):
  c = []
  array = list(array)
  for i in range(0,len(array) // size):
    frames = array[i*size:i*size+size]
    np_frames = np.asarray(frames)
    c.append(np_frames)
  perc_remainder = (len(array) / size) - (len(array) // size)
  if perc_remainder != 0:
    n_remainder = perc_remainder * size
    remainders = np.asarray(array[-1 * int(n_remainder):])
    c.append(remainders)
  return c

block512 = block(samples,512)

summation = []

rate = 2
for i in block512:
  altered_frame = manipulate(i,sr,r)
  summation.append(altered_frame)

frame_pitched512 = np.ndarray.flatten(np.asarray(summation))
frame_pitched512 = [val for sublist in summation for val in sublist]
frame_pitched512 = np.asarray(frame_pitched512)
ipd.Audio(frame_pitched512, rate=sr)
```

Actual audio and code is here:

https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1cpRhPpvXY_9XZidjOLKk_wW15EnkqLEX?usp=sharing

Lots of warnings about numba when importing librosa.

items.title: Numba deprecation move

labels.name: Upstream/dependency bug
labels.description: Another package is causing us trouble!

labels.name: good for beginners
labels.description: Are you new here?  These issues are for you!

items.body:
#### Description
Numba will remove the shim for `numba.decorators.jit` at 0.50, so we should update our import accordingly.  Since 0.48, we trigger a deprecation warning.

This should be an easy fix to `librosa.util.decorators`.

items.body:
#### Description
Error when using rms with magphase from stft using n_fft option:

I am using rms on a wave file of a length of 2048 samples and when I use the rms method as described in this way it works fine:

```
S, phase = librosa.magphase(librosa.stft(y))
rms = librosa.feature.rms(S=S)
```
But when I add the option n_fft to the stft method it gives an error which it did not give with an older version of librosa:

```
S, phase = librosa.magphase(librosa.stft(y, n_fft=512))
rms = librosa.feature.rms(S=S)
```

The error I get is:

```
librosa.util.exceptions.ParameterError: Since S.shape[0] is 257, frame_length is expected to be 512 or 513; found 2048
```

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

```
import librosa
y, sr = librosa.load(librosa.util.example_audio_file())
y = y[:2048]
S, phase = librosa.magphase(librosa.stft(y, n_fft=512))
rms = librosa.feature.rms(S=S)
```

rms calculated with success.

items.title: n_columns goes to zero for large window sizes of stft

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

items.body:
#### Description
spotted by @fzalkow in PR #1094

The STFT fails when using large window sizes. This is due to the computation of `n_columns`, which can be zero. `n_columns` is used as third argument for `range`, which must not be zero. To be honest, I don't fully get the idea of the computation of `n_columns`. I just added a quick fix to enforce that `n_columns` is at least one.


#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```python
import numpy as np 
import librosa

x = np.empty(1000000)

for exponent in range(12, 17):
    N = 2 ** exponent
    H = N // 2
    print(N, H)
    X = librosa.stft(x, n_fft=N, hop_length=H, win_length=N)
```


#### Expected Results
Pass

#### Actual Results
`ValueError: range() arg 3 must not be zero`

#### Versions
librosa 0.7.2

items.title: v0.8.0 design: Simplify file path checking (move to Pathlib?) or remove checking on Librosa's side

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

items.body:
#### Description
In Librosa v0.7.1 there was a regression due to stricter filepath checking, which rejected Pathlib objects (which was fixed in v0.7.2): https://github.com/librosa/librosa/issues/1019

This fix contains a lot of if-statements, that can be removed in v0.8.0 since support for Python 2.7 is dropped: https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/7feb1efdbc9f0c61fbee623fc03fa62410113927/librosa/core/audio.py#L142-L164

The question however is how Librosa wants to approach file path handling:
1. Move away from strings and rewrite everything to Pathlib
2. Keep it like this, but simplify the code to `isinstance(path, (six.string_types, pathlib.PurePath))`
3. Don't do anything at all
4. Remove file path checking on Librosa's side (and use try except RuntimeError)

Personally I would suggest option 4 (in optionally with 1) as it matches Python's philosophy of not checking type and instead just try if it works (https://www.reddit.com/r/Python/comments/26irhg/why_is_type_checking_not_pythonic/).
We can just let `audioread` complain if it cannot parse the arguments it's given. In the case of `SoundFile`, no `isinstance()` checking is done.

What to do about file path checking?

items.title: The default physical length is 23ms instead of 93ms

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

items.body:
#### Description
As stated in the [documentation](https://librosa.github.io/librosa/generated/librosa.core.stft.html#librosa.core.stft) the default physical length should be 93ms. Using default values to compute the mel-spectrogram does not result in a physical window length of 93ms, but rather 23ms. 
#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```
import librosa

# Load 5 seconds of audio example 
y, sr = librosa.load(librosa.util.example_audio_file(), duration=5)
# Calculate the melspctrogram with default values
S = librosa.feature.melspectrogram(y, sr)
# Print out shape of spectrogram
print(S.shape)
```

#### Expected Results
`print(S.shape)` should output `(128,54)` as 54*93ms = 5022ms = 5.022s
#### Actual Results
Output of the print is `(128,216)`, but 216*93ms = 20088ms = 20.088s
#### Versions
Python 3.8.2
NumPy 1.18.1
SciPy 1.4.1
librosa 0.7.2

items.title: to_mono - how to normalize it correctly
items.body:
Just saw `to_mono` use `np.mean` for downmixing the stereo (or any multiple) channels. This means practically, we almost always reduce the energy by downmixing it because it means `(left + right) / 2`instead of `(left + right) / sqrt(2)`.

As far as I know, the latter is more commonly used (if not always) in implementations where the downmixed signal is supposed to be played and - i.e., for the case of audio processing rather than analysis or information retrieval. Therefore maybe it's okay for Librosa to divide it by 2, but I think it's still a valid point to discuss. 

To say the least, I might want to make a PR so that it is mentioned in the doc :)

#### Description
When using the GriffinLin algorithm to reconstruct a STFT, the number of samples is shorter

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
To create the spectrogram, I have:
```
    sample_rate = librosa.get_samplerate(audio_path)
    samples, sample_rate = librosa.core.load(audio_path, sr=sample_rate)
    print('samples.shape', samples.shape)

                     win_length=n_fft, window=scipy.signal.hamming)

    spect, _ = librosa.magphase(D)
    spect = np.log1p(spect)

    spect = np.swapaxes(spect, 0, 1)

    return spect
```

items.title: Numpy FFT type promotion -> complex128

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Issues relating to docstrings, examples, and documentation build

items.body:
#### Description
By default, librosa uses the numpy fft implementation (numpy.fft) when calling librosa.get_fftlib().
That implementation will always promote input from float32 such that the output is complex128 (2 64bit floats to make the complex number) [(Numpy fft type promotion)](https://numpy.org/devdocs/reference/routines.fft.html#type-promotion).
This can silently double memory consumption in pipelines that use methods based on fft.

librosa has `scipy` as a requirement, so it would be possible to default to `scipy.fft` instead, which respects the input types.

Currently this can be achieved by doing this before running any memory-constrained code:
```
import scipy.fft as scipyfft
librosa.set_fftlib(scipyfft)
```

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

```
import librosa

S = np.float32(np.random.randn(1025))
S_cqt = librosa.cqt(S) # (uses fft internally)
print(S_cqt.dtype) # np.complex128
```

#### Expected Results
`print(S_cqt.dtype) # np.complex64`

#### Actual Results
`print(S_cqt.dtype) # np.complex128`

#### Versions
Librosa 0.7.2
